Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: I was sorting the laundry basket, mentally ticking off the chores left for the evening, when my phone buzzed. It was Jamie, my closest friend. I answered, and immediately heard the strain in their voice. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” Jamie said, voice trembling. I glanced at the overflowing basket, knowing my spouse was counting on me to get the laundry done so everyone would have clean clothes for tomorrow’s busy day. I could almost hear my partner’s earlier reminder echoing in my head: “Let’s try to stay on top of things tonight, okay?” But Jamie’s words pulled at me, too—this wasn’t just a casual chat, it was a plea for support. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in. My family needed me to keep things running smoothly, but Jamie needed me to listen, to be present. My heart raced as I stood there, phone in hand, caught between the demands of being a reliable spouse and a supportive friend, unsure which need to answer first.
